âI second the amendment.

âEven prior to the collapse of HIH and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Centre, it was evident that there were problems in the field of general insurance. Within Australia, FAI and HIH had priced their premiums unrealistically without regard to risk and, in addition, there had been a worldwide problem in reinsurance. All of these factors contributed in some way to the problems in medical indemnity insurance, which was demonstrated dramatically this year by the collapse of UMP.

speech.para: Medical indemnity is provided by the medical defence organisations. In Australia these include UMP, the Medical Defence Association of Australia, Medical Indemnity Protection Society, MDASA, MDAWA, the Medical Protection Society of Tasmania and the Queensland Doctors Mutual Ltd. It is important to understand that they are not insurers; they are not-for-profit mutuals. They do not issue insurance contracts; they protect their members in return for subscription income, and they rely on reinsurance to do this. Since 1999, four of the main MDOs have had to make a call on their members for additional funds.

I will outline some of the recent events that have occurred this year. On 3 May 2002 a provisional liquidator was appointed to UMP and its subsidiary. UMP covers 60 per cent of doctors in Australia for professional indemnity cover. We have seen subscriptions to MDOs increase dramatically. We have also seen that the MDOs have not provided for their incurred but not reported claims. In response to the collapse of UMP, on 31 May the government announced that it would assist UMP to cover payment for claims finalised and incidents between 29 April and 30 June. This was then extended to 31 December 2002.

On 23 October 2002 there was a joint announcement by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and Ageing and also the Assistant Treasurer that: firstly, the guarantee would be extended to 31 December 2003; secondly, there would be government funding for the incurred but not reported liability at 30 June 2002 where the IBNRs are unfunded; thirdly, there would be government reimbursement for medical indemnity providers, either MDOs or medical indemnity insurers, on a per claim basis for 50 per cent of the insurance payouts over $2 million for incidents notified on or after 1 January 2003âthis is the high-cost claim section; fourthly, there would be provision of premium subsidies for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural GPsâthis measure is conditional on these practitioners attending incident management and quality assurance programs; fifthly, there would be a cost recovery which would consist of a levy on members for the unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities and payments would be made by members of the MDOs to the Commonwealth to cover the cost to the Commonwealth of payments in relation to those unfunded IBNR liabilities; and lastly, medical indemnity insurance providers would have prudential supervision from APRA and would act more commercially in future. Changes in accounting standards will require the MDOs to include IBNRs on their balance sheets and provision for them.

This legislation comprises four bills which implement the measures which were announced on 23 October 2002, except for the prudential supervision by APRA. I welcome the announcement of 23 October as a good, commonsense outcome and a good approach to the vexed question of professional indemnity insurance and medical indemnity insurance in this case.

The Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 are both taxation bills. To satisfy section 55 of the Constitution, which states that laws imposing taxation shall only deal with the imposition of taxation and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect, they are separate bills. But the main bill is the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, which is under debate at the moment along with the other ones.

I will now refer to the IBNR indemnity scheme. Where MDOs have not provided for the incurred but not reported liabilities, the Commonwealth will meet the liabilities as they fall due but they will also levy doctors to cover the cost. This will allow the MDOs to continue without being burdened by past IBNRs. It allows in essence a fresh start. Division 1 of part 2 of this bill provides that, if MDOs do not have enough money to fund their IBNRs, the Commonwealth will pay money to the MDOs providing that the MDOs are participating MDOs. Whether they are participating MDOs is subject to ministerial discretion. If, for example, an MDO does have sufficient funds to pay their IBNR then the minister can determine that the fund is non-participating. This covers incidents occurring before 30 June 2002 but notified after 30 June 2002. The MDO will make the payment and will then be reimbursed by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth may pay all or a percentage of the claim. This is covered in clauses 21 to 23 of this bill. The proportion of the payment will be assessed by the Australian Government Actuary to reflect the proportion of the participating MDO's IBNR liabilities which are unfunded. There is an important exception to this: IBNR payments will not be made for an incident relating to a public patient in a public hospital. I presume that is because the coverage is provided by the state governments in that case.

I turn to the part of the bill which relates to high-cost claims. The Commonwealth's partial coverage of high-cost claims will improve the affordability of premiums, it will improve the bottom line of the medical defence organisations, and it may even encourage new entrants to come into the marketâwhich at the moment, without these changes, is not an attractive market to be in.

Clauses 29 and 30 in division 2 of the bill provide that the Commonwealth will pay 50 per cent of insurance payments over $2 million. The 50 per cent figure can be changed by regulation. This will apply to a claim in Australia which is notified after 1 January 2003 and is greater than $2 million or an amount which can be changed by regulation and where the medical defence organisation has paid the amount or is liable to pay. Once again, there is an exception for incidents involving public patients in public hospitals and I assume that is for the reason that their liability is covered by the state governments.

Clause 43 of the bill, dealing with the medical indemnity subsidy scheme, states that the minister can determine medical practitioners who will receive a subsidy for the medical indemnity premiums. On 23 October, the Prime Minister stated that this would apply to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralists, and there are good reasons why those professional groups are included. This measure will help to make premiums more affordable for these groups. These groups have major affordability issues relative to their incomes and relative to their professional peers in the specialties for obstetricians and neurosurgeons, but also for GP proceduralists.

The subsidy will be 50 per cent of the difference between the premium and the incurred but not reported levy for the obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural GPs, relative to those of gynaecologists, general surgeons and non-procedural GPs. So we will be looking at the difference between the risk premiums of an obstetrician and a gynaecologist, a neurosurgeon and a general surgeon, and a procedural GP and a non-procedural GP. Obstetricians and neurosurgeons are high-risk subspecialties and are associated with high premiums. They are not high income for a specialist group, and they spend up to one-third of their Medicare income on premiums. Neurosurgeons pay high premiums and have limited capacity to earn income from private practice, and so another section of the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 provides that the subsidy will be 80 per cent for the premium plus the levy where it is over $50,000. Obstetricians, neurosurgeons and orthopaedic surgeons are often included in the three specialties that pay the highest premiums, but orthopaedic surgeons are not included here. An examination of their premiums showed that around the states their premiums are much lower than those of obstetricians and neurosurgeons: approximately $25,000 in 2001-02.

I move to procedural GPs. In general, this group most commonly practises in rural and remote areas and has a low volume of procedural services, so it is difficult to recoup the cost of the medical indemnity for services such as obstetrics. But they provide a very important service, and without having this sort of cover we would lose the procedures these general practitioners are able to perform in rural and remote areas.

Part 3 of the bill deals with financing the schemes. Division 1 sets out that all members of a participating MDO as at 30 June 2000 are required to make a contribution unless they have died, retired before 31 December 2000, were a student at 30 June 2000 or have alternative insurance. The rate is based on the indemnity premium or subscription paid by the members. This will only apply to doctors who belong to an MDO with an unfunded incurred but not reported liability as at 30 June 2002. Doctors who are members of an MDO that has funded its IBNR liabilities will not need to pay a levy. Paying the levy is a more affordable option for the medical profession than the past method, which was the MDO making a call on its members or introducing higher premiums. We saw that several times with UMP. The levy can be paid in a lump sum or by instalments, or it can be deferred for a yearâfor example, if the members take time out of the work force or go overseas. The levy is expected to run for five years to make it affordable. The annual amount will be limited to 50 per cent of a doctor's 2000-01 premium, and the levy is also tax-deductible.

Division 2 of part 3 of the bill sets out that members of the UMP as at 1 July 2002 must pay a contribution to cover the cost of the Commonwealth guarantee to the provisional liquidator of UMP, AMIL, covering 1 July 2002 to 31 December 2003. With regard to the UMP indemnity contributions, UMP members are required to pay the levy if UMP goes into liquidation, under the deed of indemnity between the Commonwealth, UMP and the provisional liquidators. I turn to the financial impact of the bill. It is estimated that the annual cost of high-cost claims is $19 million to $35 million, although this depends on the progress and nature of state tort law reform. The other impacts have already been included in the 2001-02 budget impact.

The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons has proposed a single medical defence organisation. There is nothing to stop any of the seven existing MDOs merging with another; that is really a matter for them. It is of course also subject to the Trade Practices Act and the ACCC. However, size is not everything; UMP shows us that. They had a 60 per cent market share but still were not able to price their premiums properly.

This bill provides an important response to the collapse of UMP and also to the difficulties medical defence organisations have. There are also some long-term measures, which the opposition spokesman on health spoke about and which are being addressed by the government. First of all, tort law reform is the subject of negotiations with the states. We are already starting to see some cases in the state court systems overturning previous cases in terms of medical negligence and the definitions thereof. Also, long-term care costs will be helped by the high-cost claims scheme. That scheme covers high-cost claims greater than $2 million. It is important to make the point that the number of catastrophically injured as a result of medical negligence is very small compared with the whole population. Motor vehicle accidents, for example, are much more common. This is an area of direct responsibility for the states. They have the infrastructure in place to assist people with catastrophic injuries. So it is up to the states to explore the feasibility of allowing a victim of medical negligence access to the services provided under these schemes. We want to see access to services rather than a new bureaucracy. While I sympathise with those who have family or friends who have been catastrophically injured, there is, as I said, existing infrastructure in the states.

I turn to the issue of clinical risk management. Any doctor receiving a subsidyâand that includes that group of obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralistsâmust do quality and service safety activities as a result of the Commonwealth assistance. There are other initiatives of the government which are operating on a much wider systemic scaleâfor example, the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care, chaired by Bruce Barraclough, which is promoting improvement in safety issues. They divide it into priority areas: one, supporting those who work in the health system; two, improving data and information for safer health care; three, involving consumers in improving health care safety; four, redesigning systems to facilitate a culture of safety; and, five, building awareness and understanding of health care safety. Some of the practical things the council are focusing on are, firstly, reducing patient harm associated with medication use; secondly, reducing patient harm resulting from health care associated infections; thirdly, coordinating national action to learn from serious events; and, lastly, developing national standards to support more open disclosure to patients and their carers.

Last of all, the high-cost claims scheme will help to reduce reinsurance costs. This could encourage new entrants. By improving the market conditions, our medical defence organisations would be in a good position to negotiate their reinsurance contracts because of the high-cost claims scheme. We think it is more important for us to make this a more attractive market than to negotiate on behalf of the MDOs. Our expertise is not in insurance. We are not in the insurance business. This legislation has been introduced in response to a crisis in medical indemnity, but we believe it is more important to improve market conditions than to represent the MDOs in the reinsurance treaties. We are not in the insurance business.

talk.start.para: âWhilst the opposition is not opposing the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and related bills, I would like to place on the record my absolute disgust at the government's handling of this matter. Its handling of the medical indemnity insurance crisis has left a lot to be desired. In doing so, I would like to support the amendments moved by the member for Perth. I have to condemn the government for the way it has vacillated, procrastinated and delayed bringing in this legislation. In doing that, I would like to put on record that it is not only members of the opposition and the constituents we speak to on a day-to-day basis but also the doctors who have been relying on the government to resolve this matter and to resolve it a lot quicker than it has done. Doctors have been very concerned about the delay in coming up with any viable, long-term solution to this problem.

speech.para: The government's action in this area has really left a lot to be desired. As well as creating uncertainty for the medical profession, it has created uncertainty for mums, dads and their children in my electorate and electorates throughout Australia. When the crisis first eventuated, various doctors closed their doors because they were so uncertain as to the future, and it left a great void. Here we are six months later and we finally have legislation. It is not the full answer to the problem, but we are a little bit further down the track than we were before the government announced these measures. They are a starting point. The states and territories moved a lot quicker than the federal government did. In New South Wales, the health minister announced that all doctors working in the public system would be covered, and there have been moves to change the tort laws in the states. Unfortunately, I must compare this to the response of the federal government, which vacillated and delayed making a decision. That is something we have come to expect from this government, unless it is about introducing legislation that is going to benefit its friends.

Finally, after much delay, the government did come up with the legislation we are debating today. As I have mentioned, this delay jeopardised patient care and the delivery of health services and created this uncertainty and other things I will mention as I continue. This has been symbolic of the government's performance in the area of health. On 23 October, the government announced a package of measures to address the rising medical indemnity insurance premiums and to ensure viable, ongoing medical indemnity coverage. In particular, the government announced an extension of the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltdâthat is, to extend their cover to 31 December next year. I hope that, on 3 December next year, I am not standing in this House debating legislation to extend it for another 12 months. It was only on 17 October that we debated legislation to extend the cover to the end of this year. To my way of thinking, that is not the way to handle an issue as important as this one. People need certainty. Doctors need certainty and their patients need certainty. I have to be very critical, because I do not think this delivers that long-term certainty.

There are partial subsidies for insurance premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs performing surgery. That is a most welcome measure. In the area that I represent that has been quite a problem and there has been a great reduction in the number of obstetricians and neurosurgeons. As I highlighted in the speech I made in October, there are only three obstetricians, to the best of my knowledge, working privately in the Newcastle area. This situation has been allowed to develop by a government that is a champion of the private sector. It has encouraged Australian families to take out private health insurance and it has put a lot of money in insurance as opposed to the actual health system. It has failed to provide enough certainty and coverage for obstetricians, and a similar situation exists for neurosurgeons. The number of neurosurgeons in both the Hunter and the Central Coast has declined significantly. Traditionally, the brightest medical students went into specialties like neurosurgery and obstetrics, and now they are steering away from those because of concerns about medical indemnity insurance and cases that could come up in the future.

The government announced a scheme to meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million up to the insured amount made by medical indemnity insurers. There is also a levy to recoup the cost of funding the incurred but not reported, IBNR, liabilities of medical defence organisations that have not set aside money to cover these liabilities. Also, these organisations are to be brought into a new regulatory framework administered by APRA. The ACCC will monitor medical indemnity premiums to determine whether they are actuarial or commercially justifiable.

This is good, but it is too little too late. While these announcements and this legislation are welcome, unfortunately I do not see that it will solve the problem in the long term. They are short-term measures that seek to stabilise the situationâstabilise the increasing costs of premiumsârather than providing a long-term solution to the problem. These measures are not proactive; they are reactive. They are reacting to a situation that exists now and are not offering a long-term solution.

One thing that really concerns me is the failure of this package to address the professional indemnity needs of health care professionals such as midwives. In the Hunter there is only one midwife practising privately. She is about to leave the area and will not be replaced. She is moving to northern New South Wales, and it is my understanding that she will not be practising as a midwife because she feels she cannot continue in the current environment. This is a result of the government's failure to address this problem. It has taken away an option for those midwives who are practising privately, particularly in the area of homebirth. I would not like to mislead the parliament: once this midwife leaves there will be no midwives practising or prepared to work in the area of homebirth in the area I represent. The bill also fails to mention issues relating to allied health professionals.

This legislation is a short-term fix, not a long-term solution. I compare the government's handling of this issue to its handling of the bulk-billing issueâit is very similar. In the Shortland electorate in 1999-2000, 78.6 per cent of all medical services were bulk-billed. The latest figures I have show that that has declined to 57 per cent. That is a mammoth decline. Back in 2000, the government commissioned the relative value study of the work performed by GPs. That relative value study showed that the GPs should receive in excess of $40 per consultation. The government failed to act on that, and the AMA and the government were not talking and the issue was not being addressed. That led to a greater decline in bulk-billing services. Who does it hurt? It hurts the families, the pensioners and the veterans that each of us represent in this place. I think the saddest thing of all is that very few GPs are bulk-billing pensioners. All members of this House would know that acceptance of the gold card by GPs is in jeopardy as well.

In my area the decline in bulk-billing has been made worse. That is because one of the first acts of this government was to close a Medicare office that was at least in the vicinity, making it easier for people living in the area to collect their money. They now have to travel a lot further and, particularly where you have an elderly population, that can be a problem because many people have restricted driving licences. I spoke on the telephone with one lady today. She said that her mother, who has been going to a doctor for many years, attended his surgery the other day and was advised that he no longer bulk-billed. Her mother did not know what to do. She had never been to a Medicare office and, because the local Medicare office had been closed, she had to travel some distance. Being 88 years old, the mother had to be driven by the daughter, and the daughter also had to fill out the forms. This caused great anxiety for the mother.

My issue here and how it relates to what we are debating tonight is that, if you allow things to slide, if you do not consult and talk to the people who are involved, the situation will deteriorate. It is very similar to the fact that we have a doctor shortage on the Central Coast in the area that I represent. The desired ratio is one GP per 1,000 people; on the northern part of the Central Coast, there is one GP to every 2,500 people. Certain communities are not only without a doctor who bulk-bills; they are without a doctorâand it is my understanding that the situation is deteriorating. The government promised the allocation of 150 doctors to outlying areas of the six major capital cities; we have seen none being allocated to the area I represent. The government's latest idea of sending failed specialists to work as GPs is not only unacceptable to general practitioners but unacceptable to the people that I and most of us represent in this House. The government refused to act and it refused to negotiate with the GPsâand here we have a crisis relating to bulk-billing. That crisis will continue under this government; it is only the opposition, which is listening to the people, that is prepared to act.

Another thing that I have done is to send a survey out to the people in my electorate of Shortland. To date, I have had 2,500-plus responses to that survey. Overwhelmingly, the most important health issue for my constituents is having a doctor who bulk-bills. Once again, the government has not acted, letting down the people whom I represent in this place.

Certain things need to be done to resolve the medical indemnity insurance problem. One is that the government needs to show a little more leadership and coordinate national reforms, a national approach. Unfortunately, it has failed to do this. We need uniformity in tort law, and to date this government has not been able to deliver there. It is unable to show leadership. It specialises in creating division and sitting on its hands. We need mandatory reporting of negligence claims and a national data collection of health care negligence cases to help assess where the major problems lie and what the issues are. Until we have that, the problem within the medical system will continue. We really need a government that is prepared to consult, to talk to people.

In Oregon, Oregon Health Services undertook a studyâand I mentioned this in a speech I made in the House on 17 October. The spokesman for that project was Larry Baker. In Oregon they found that they were able to dramaticallyâand I mean really dramaticallyâreduce the costs of medical negligence claims simply by communicating and talking with people. If the health service there makes a mistake and there is a problemâif a person has a complaint, a relative has been lost or somebody is unsatisfied with the medical treatment they have receivedâthey admit it. Rather than going to ground and refusing to accept responsibility, they admit that they have made a mistake. They talk about it and they resolve the problem. Further to what I have mentioned so far, consideration needs to be given to putting in place a national scheme to ensure long-term care and rehabilitation. A much more active role must be played in keeping reinsurance costs down, working and negotiating with medical defence organisations and improving clinical outcomes.

This legislation should not be considered as a solution to the problem of medical indemnity insurance. Rather, it is a start, and much more is needed. It is a disgrace that here we are, six months down the track, debating this legislation today. It is a disgrace that three months ago we debated legislation that covered us until the end of this year. I certainly hope that this time next year we are not back here debating similar legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI welcome the introduction of the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and associated bills and I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this important debate on medical indemnity insurance. The aim of the government's legislation is to provide for the long-term sustainability and affordability of medical indemnity insurance for Australian doctors.

speech.para: Following the placing into liquidation of United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd, the government put in place temporary arrangements to ensure that medical services would continue without disruption. The financial situation being experienced by the medical indemnity organisations and the increasing costs of indemnity insurance were cause for strong and decisive action by the government.

The deterioration in the financial health of the funds is to be lamented. Many questions have been asked, and will continue to be asked, about how they came to find themselves in such a parlous state. Nevertheless, without the government implementing the new measures, the ability of our medical practitioners to continue to provide the vital services they do provide to the Australian people would have suffered greatly. The government has provided a guarantee to cover claims within a specified period, allowing doctors to continue to practise in the knowledge that claims will be met.

At the same time, the Prime Minister announced the government's proposals for dealing with the unfunded incurred but not reported liabilitiesâknown as IBNRsâof the funds. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 has been introduced to deal specifically with this issue. Through this measure, the government will establish which funds have IBNRs and have failed to set aside money to cover their liabilities. The government will then fund these liabilities but will recoup this cost through a levy on the fund's members which will be payable over an extended period. This levy will apply only to those funds which have not funded their IBNRs. Doctors who are members of a medical indemnity organisation that has funded its IBNRs will not be subject to the levy. This is the only fair and equitable way of resolving this issue. It would not be right for the Australian taxpayer to carry the entire burden; at the same time, without this funding doctors would have faced much higher premiums which they would have been forced to pay over a short period.

By this measure, the government has made the cost of funding these liabilities more affordable. Doctors who have to pay the levy because their medical indemnity organisation has not funded its IBNRs will have several options. They can pay the levy in a lump sum and enjoy a discount, they can pay by instalments or they can defer payment for a year. The levy, which is tax deductible, will probably run over five years; the annual amount which a doctor pays will be limited to 50 per cent of their 2000-01 premium.

To properly safeguard doctors in the future, the medical indemnity organisations will now be subjected to a range of prudential safeguards to reduce the risk of their insolvency. A new regulatory framework will be established by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. From now on, medical indemnity organisations must report their IBNRs on their balance sheets and make provision for them.

Let us be quite clear on this. In the past some organisations had not provided adequately for their incurred but not reported liabilities. Some have seen the error of this and in recent years have changed their financial practices to ensure that all of their liabilities are fully funded. As a result of the government's strong actions, all medical indemnity organisations will now have to not only show the level of all of their liabilities but also make adequate provision for them. It is important for the sake of the medical profession to maintain choice in the provision of medical indemnity insurance. The competitive marketplace usually provides the most affordable and best quality service available, with an appropriate regulatory framework.

In order to safeguard the public by ensuring that doctors can continue to practise with adequate medical indemnity insurance cover, the government has strengthened the regulatory requirements. At the same time it has provided the means by which the mistakes of the past can be paid for fairly and affordably.

The government has also been mindful of the problem of increasing costs of medical indemnity insurance premiums. This legislation will ease the pressure on doctors, through the high-cost claims scheme, under which the government will provide assistance for the cost of large claims. Medical indemnity organisations will pay out less on big claims, leading to a reduction in the amount of reinsurance they have to purchase, and this should have a positive effect on premiums.

The bill also provides for premium subsidies for specific groups of doctors who undertake high-risk specialties but whose expertise and service to their patients are vital. These doctors have suffered from particularly large increases in their premiums during recent times, and the government will provide subsidies to help them afford the cost of their premiums while the broader reform package takes full effect. This will serve to address a key concern of many medical practitioners.

Ultimately the sustainability of the medical indemnity insurance industry depends on improving patient safety. I understand that, after consultation with medical professionals and their industry representatives, the minister has been encouraged by their desire and willingness to improve clinical risk management and reduce the incidence of patient injury.

At the local level, I have seen the willingness of health professionals to improve the care and safety of their patients through the introduction of prescribing safeguards in an aged care facility in my electorate. A joint project between the University of South Australia, Helping Hand Aged Care and the Adelaide North East Division of General Practice will provide doctors caring for patients with the Helping Hand Aged Care facilities with access to the same prescribing information that is available in their surgeries. The benefit to residents will come from the improved levels of safety and quality in the prescribing of their medicines.

Medication errors, and their often adverse effects, are a problem which occurs not only in Australia but throughout the world. It is particularly pleasing to see that one solution to this problem is being implemented here in South Australia. Dr Chris Bollen of the Adelaide North East Division of General Practice has advised me that the idea for this project came about as a result of his reading the recommendations of the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care, a federal government initiative. It is always pleasing to see that the valuable expert advice and information generated by such bodies is utilised effectively within our community. I wish to personally congratulate Dr Bollen and Professor Jim Warren of the University of South Australia. Thanks must also go to the dedicated management, Dr Milton Hart and staff, whose hard work and enthusiasm for this project have seen it become a reality. For residents of Helping Hand Aged Care, it must be a comfort to know that their interests are being well served by so many talented people.

Finally, in dealing with claims made by patients against their doctors, we must recognise that such matters need to be kept in a proper perspective. As with other areas of tort law, we must not go down the American path of excessively high levels of litigation. We are, unfortunately, becoming a more litigious society and doctors are just as human as the rest of us: mistakes will be made no matter how careful and cautious we are. Moves to allow medical professionals to offer an apology to patients or the patient's family without condemning himself or herself to a financial malpractice suit are steps in the right direction. It may be an often used phrase, but a little bit of basic commonsense is what may be lacking in some instances, along with a little humanity and understanding. These bills address some of the underlying structural problems of the medical indemnity insurance industry and will reduce the pressure on premiums that doctors have to pay. Ultimately it will be for the state and territory jurisdictions to tackle the problems of tort law reform which are at the heart of this issue. As the chair of the health and aged care committee, I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and associated bills which we are debating in the House tonight give effect to significant elements of the government's policy on medical indemnity insurance which were announced on 23 October 2002. These bills are a response to a crisis situation in the medical profession that should have been reasonably anticipated by the government. Once again, the incompetence of this government has been seriously exposed by the public record of events in relation to this complex area of medical indemnity insurance.

speech.para: These bills contain three important measures to assist the medical profession in addressing the issue of steeply rising medical insurance premiums and they introduce a measure of certainty and stability to the medical insurance market. In typical fashion, the debacle in the medical insurance area mirrors what has happened in many policy areas where this government and its ministers, in their incompetence, have failed to act decisively to head off crises and collapses in the corporate area. At the end of the day, that incompetence has cost industry dearly and a huge burden has been placed on ordinary Australians. In the collapse of HIH, the Treasurer and his prudential regulator failed in their administrative duty. The pieces of the Treasurer's incompetence are still being picked up by football clubs, pony clubs, local governments, tourism businesses and doctors.

In the Ansett and OneTel collapses, the government ministers were asleep at the wheel, and there were horrendous impacts on the lives of employees and, in Ansett's case, on regional businesses which were particularly reliant on the continued operation of that airline. There is one disturbing characteristic of these collapses and crises: the sheer incompetence of government ministers in failing to act decisively in emergency crises. Now we can add another crisis to the list: the crisis in medical indemnity insurance.

In announcing a package to meet the ongoing crisis, the government outlined a number of measures to address the problems that have emerged in the medical indemnity insurance field. They are an extension of the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd to 31 December 2003; partial subsidies for insurance premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs performing procedures; a scheme to meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million, up to the insured amount, made by medical indemnity insurers; funding of the incurred but not reported liabilities for those medical defence organisations that have not set aside money to cover these liabilities; a levy to recoup the cost of funding for IBNR liabilities for members of the relevant medical defence organisations over an extended period; medical defence organisations to be brought into a new regulatory framework administered by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority; and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to monitor medical indemnity insurance premiums to determine whether they are actuarially and commercially justified.

This package of bills gives effect to basically three elements of the October announcements. Firstly, it provides a scheme to assist those medical defence organisations which have unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities as at 30 June 2002 to meet those claims when they come onstream. Secondly, it provides a high-cost claims scheme aimed at lowering premiums by reducing the high cost of claims related to medical incidents. Thirdly, it provides a subsidy to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs who undertake Medicare billable procedures.

I do not propose to canvass the complexity of these bills. Suffice it to say that, had the government acted earlier to address this crisis, the Australian taxpayer might have been spared the $246.5 million outlay over four years that is now required to address the very serious problems that emerged in the medical insurance indemnity market. The opposition will support the bill, but we have moved a second reading amendment that offers some scope for debate and discussion on matters affecting the provision and cost of medical indemnity insurance to GPs and other medical specialists, and other associated matters. As members appreciate, the services provided by doctors are not always provided in hospitals or surgeries. Doctors are called on at the scene of emergencies, in the home when a person is taken seriously ill or is convalescing, and in places such as nursing homes and hostels where care to the aged is delivered.

In the case of the latter, the ongoing quality of care and the physical safety of the aged are important elements of the total package of care provided by doctors, health care professionals and aged care providers within the ambit of their establishments. Regrettably, in recent years there has been an ongoing problem in maintaining and improving standards of care in many aged care establishments. This factor, coupled with the uncertainty created for doctors by the medical indemnity crisis, has led some GPs and specialists to question whether they are able to maintain a regime of regular visits to older people who reside in certain aged care establishments.

Last night in the adjournment debate in this House I raised on behalf of constituents very serious matters relating to a proposal to extend the Glenburn nursing home in Drumcondra in my electorate. In that speech I raised two major questions relating to the process of planning approval for the extension of that facility and the granting of a licence for 30 extra beds at the facility. I said in that speech that the two central questions that I raised spawned a myriad of ancillary questions relating to council approval processes, planning considerations, VCAT deliberations, care and safety of the aged at Glenburn, residents' rights and the appropriateness of nursing home developments in the region. I do not propose to canvass all of those matters here; however, I would like to refer to one aspectâthe care and safety of older people at Glenburn nursing home should this development proceed, because it raises the sorts of care issues of real concern to doctors and other health professionals involved with the care of the aged at this nursing home and similar facilities and their reluctance to provide that care in potentially risky environments.

The government allocated 30 extra beds to Glenburn following a submission for 30 additional beds, which was prepared by Mr Chris Whitehead on behalf of the proprietor, Jeff Alexander, and the company that runs the Glenburn nursing home. In August 2000, a site audit was done of the Glenburn nursing home, and Mr Whitehead was part of that assessment team. The facility in question is a nursing home which is currently located in a residential area. The proposed extension would see this facility expanded to incorporate a two-storey facility located in that area. There are serious questions being asked as to how the facility was able to get through the planning processes. There are legitimate concerns expressed by the residents of my electorate. They have also raised very important and serious concerns about this two-storey nursing home development in a residential area where parking is restricted and where the fire safety provisions can be questioned. They also raise concerns about the ultimate care of clients in this facility.

I raised this nursing home as an example because I have had doctors who service clients in that facility complain about the risks that will exist for older people in that extended facility, and they have told me of their own reluctance, if this development should proceed, to service older people in that environment. I would like to reinforce the concerns of those doctors who have raised the issue of medical indemnity insurance should they be forced into a situation of discharging their medical duty to their older patients and servicing those patients in what they regard as inappropriate aged care establishments. In a letter to Minister Andrews about the proposed development, local resident Mrs Lois Trounson said:

quote.para: I have lived at my present address for over 60 years and the proposed nursing home would back on to my backyard. I am at a loss to understand why someone who has been pursued through the AAT, Supreme Court, High Supreme Court, back to the AAT, to close him down in Tasmania and attempt to wind him up in Geelong can have an application for 30 additional beds and funding approved.

speech.para: This is a constituent referring to an aged care facility in which older people reside and which doctors have said to me they may not service because of the risks associated with the older people residing in this expanded facility. Mrs Trounson continues:

quote.para: Another great concern to me is the fact that the developer has gained a permit for a facility that the CFA has indicated could pose a huge problem in the event of a fire. They have stated that they would be unable to gain access to the rear of the property via the back laneâthe only means of access. I am 94 years old and would be very uncomfortable knowing that I was on a second storey of a building, which, if it caught fire, would pose a real problem for firefighters to gain accessâand I am not a nursing home candidate. Therefore I hold very real fears for the welfare of the patients should this facility proceed.

speech.para: That is a concern that has been echoed by a doctor who lives in the same street as this nursing home and who is frequently called on to attend the residents of that nursing home. Mrs Trounson goes on to say in her letter:

quote.para: There is a great deal of far more desirable locations in the Geelong area for the hospital. These alternate locations would provide a superior quality of life (eg. greenery, larger bedrooms, bathrooms, lounge areas etc.) rather than cramming this facility in an already busy neighbourhood, and on [an] already extremely busy road. The proposed setting is totally inappropriate for many more reasons than the ones I have stated.

speech.para: Those reasons have been brought to my attention by a whole range of constituents in this locality who are concerned about this development. The most interesting objection has come from doctors who service the facility now, who see real dangers for nursing home residents should this expansion proceed in this residential area and who have questioned, in the face of this medical indemnity insurance crisis, whether they have the capacity in the futureâin what they perceive to be a medically and physically risky environmentâto service the needs of the residents of that particular facility.

I mention this because in so many ways the medical indemnity insurance crisis is affecting ordinary Australians. The shadow minister has outlined in debate how this particular crisis could undermine bulk-billingâthe pillar, the cornerstone, of Medicare, that great Labor initiative and universal health scheme that has won the endorsement of Australians over several decades. It is very important that we retain that Medicare system and bulk-billing, and it is very important that we overcome this particular crisis in medical indemnity insuranceâbecause it has the potential, over time, to undermine one of the great health insurance and health care systems in the world.

I raise these matters related to the Glenburn nursing home because I think they add a certain dimension to this debate. The dimension is simply this: doctors in my communityâin the place where I liveâhave raised some very serious objections to the expansion of this facility at its present location. They have not objected to the relocation of this facility to a new, alternative area that is more appropriate; they are saying that the residents of that nursing home at this time, and future residents, may well be at risk should that development proceed. If it does proceed then they would seriously consider, given the current medical indemnity insurance arrangements, whether or not they would be able to provide services to the older people in that environment. It is a serious issue. It is a local dimension, if you like, to this debate.

Today I met with the Minister for Ageing on this matter and I must say I was heartened by the discussions I had with him. He listened attentively to the points that I made with regard to this nursing home and he gave an undertaking to examine the matter to its fullest extent. I should also acknowledge here the contribution of the member for Corangamite on this issue. Although his electorate is on the other side of the Barwon River, he has taken an interest in the issue and has also made approaches to the minister, which I am grateful for. The honourable member for Corangamite and I, as many members would know, have had many stoushes on the floor of this House, on a range of issues. But on some issues we do come together in the interests of the community of Geelong. This may not seem a big issue to some but it is an important issue. It is important because it relates to the care provided by doctors to older Australiansâdoctors who question their ability to deliver that care under current medical indemnity insurance arrangements. We will be supporting the general thrust of this legislation before the House because it is necessary in order to underpin the provision of medical services to working Australians on an ongoing basis.

talk.start.para: âI rise in the House to speak on the issue of provision of medical indemnity insurance. The four bills that the government has put before the House provide security to doctors and stability for the provision of health care in Australia. There has been great concern in the community over the issue of medical indemnity insurance, and the government has acted to address these concerns. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 act to address the issue of medical indemnity.

speech.para: The federal coalition has an outstanding record in addressing the health needs of all Australians and in particular the needs of people in rural and regional Australia. The issue of medical indemnity insurance is of course an important matter that the federal government has made a priority since the collapse of United Medical Protection. These bills currently before the House will assist in reducing the cost of medical insurance and ensure that medical services, particularly in regional and rural Australia, are maintained.

The National Party and this government are absolutely committed to ensuring that first-class medical services are provided to the people of regional and rural Australia. This is evidenced by the regional health strategy announced in the 2000 budget, which provided $562 million over four years to improve access to health services for people living in regional and rural areas. No other Commonwealth government has ever invested such a significant amount of funding to enable long-term systematic reform of rural and regional health services. The regional health strategy builds on the success of the coalition's many innovations in rural health such as the GP retention program, the John Flynn scholarship and other landmark initiatives to get more doctors and services into country areas.

There are a number of issues which the National Party has pushed for and the federal government has adopted in their focus on improving health services in rural and regional areas. The regional health strategy provides $210 million over four years to increase the number of doctors, specialists and allied health professionals working in country Australia. These initiatives include $102.1 million to increase the number of GPs in regional Australia. This year, 200 out of 450 vocational postgraduate training places for general practice will be located in regional and rural Australia resulting in an immediate increase in access to GP services for those in the country.

Another initiative is the registrars program for trainee specialist GPs who can earn an extra $60,000 over three years by training in a rural area. The strategy includes $48.4 million for greater specialist access in regional Australia, including funding for incentives and travel costs for specialists to conduct outreach specialty work and to act as mentors for local health professionals to help them increase their skills.

There is $49.5 million to fund increased allied health services in country Australia. Physiotherapy, nursing, podiatry and psychology will be provided to assist local GPS in caring for their community. The government also implemented the Rural Retention Program in 1999âa world first initiative which rewards long-serving doctors with annual bonuses based on the length of their service and the remoteness of their practice. This $60 million program is to assist rural communities to keep their doctors. To date, payments totalling approximately $20 million have been paid to over 1,600 GPs in regional and rural Australia. But the retention of highly skilled health professionals in regional areas will become all the more difficult, unless it is backed by these medical indemnity bills.

It is important to note that some of the programs which are now in place are initiatives which will increase the level of health services provided to country Australia. We must remember that the delivery of health services in such areas is dependent on an integrated approach which spreads across all professionals involved in medical care. For example, having a viable medical indemnity insurance market will allow our nurses to continue their good work. As many of our colleagues will be aware, for the first time ever the federal government is providing support for practice nurses to improve the level of care Australians receive. The 2001 budget announced $104.3 million to allow general practices to employ more nurses, especially benefiting those living in regional and outer metropolitan areas.

Additionally, $13 million is funding 100 new nursing scholarships worth $10,000 each to encourage more students with a regional and rural background to study nursing and to address the shortage of nurses in country areas. We have also seen the establishment of rural work force agencies in each state and the Northern Territory to look at the needs of different remote communities and help them recruit and retain their doctors through a range of initiatives. This support is worth approximately $14 million per year.

To assist in delivering more doctors to rural and regional Australia, the regional health strategy provides $162 million over four years to support rural GPs' training and educational needs. The initiatives include nine new clinical schools and three new university departments of rural health being established at a cost of $117.6 million. This announcement has complemented the seven university departments that the government has established in each state and the Northern Territory since 1996 to focus on issues associated with rural health work force development. The clinical schools will ensure that senior-year medical students receive comprehensive training in the practice and procedures they will need for rural practice. There is $32.4 million from the regional health strategy to create 100 scholarships worth $20,000 per year for medical students willing to practice in rural areas for a period of at least six years. Funding will also be provided to create 100 new places within university medical schools around the country.

Also, $8 million has been provided under the Rural Australia Medical Undergraduate Scholarship Scheme to enable more students with a rural background to undertake medical training. This extra funding effectively doubles the number of places available to 400. Medical graduates have the opportunity to work off their HECS debt. One-fifth of the HECS debt will be forgone for each year worked in a designated regional area at a cost of some $4.3 million. The government has extended the John Flynn scholarship to ensure that this year nearly 600 medical students will receive financial support to work in a country environment with a doctor mentor. The coalition established the James Cook University Medical School in Townsville at a cost of $10 million and the University of New South Wales Clinical School in Wagga at a cost of $13.2 million.

The value of all of these initiatives depends on the existence of an affordable medical insurance market. The absence of a solid and acceptable medical indemnity insurance market effectively eliminates the incentive for many professionals to work. This would place at risk many of the services I have just mentioned which have been introduced at great expense to improve the level of service provision in regional and rural Australia.

There is a range of other issues, such as $68.9 million to expand the Regional Health Services Program; $41.6 million would be spent on rural pharmacy maintenance allowance to provide assistance for the start-up of pharmacies and also to assist in keeping existing pharmacies; and small non-government hospitals in rural areas will be assisted by the $30.3 million funding being used to revitalise bush nursing hospitals to refurbish, restructure, be run more efficiently and enhance the quality of care they offer their remote communities. The strategy also allocates $14.2 million to develop and implement the chronic disease support package for small rural and regional communities to deal with conditions such as asthma, diabetes, renal failure and depression. Another $32 million was committed to increase the Medicare rebate for other medical practitionersâGPs who are not vocationally registered who practise in rural and regional Australia.

In the 2001-02 budget, the coalition allocated $43.4 million to establish 32 after-hours primary medical care sites across Australia. These sites will be set up in collaboration with local GPs and will aim to provide additional services to predominantly outer metropolitan and rural areas where current access and services are poor. The measures I have mentioned demonstrate, as I have said previously, the depth of commitment this government has to providing health services in regional and rural areas. Country services are disproportionately affected by the increases in medical indemnity insurance because of the low volume of some procedures compared to city practices. We must support our rural health initiatives with reforms in the area of medical indemnity.

This package of bills focuses on premium affordability for doctors and on ensuring the viability of medical indemnity organisations or MDOs into the future. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 will provide for determining which medical defence organisations have unfunded incurred but not reported liabilitiesâIBNRs. It will also allow the Commonwealth to make payments in relation to claims forming part of the unfunded IBNR liability of MDOs as at 30 June 2002 and in relation to high-cost claims and subsidies for certain medical practitioners. I know that health professionals who practise in the Cowper electorate are facing increased costs in premiums because of substantial insurance payouts.

These bills will allow the Commonwealth to make payments for part of the costs of large claims against MDOs or medical indemnity insurers in relation to incidents notified after 1 January 2003. Subsidies will also be accessible to assist medical practitioners, specifically neurosurgeons, obstetricians and gynaecologists, to meet the cost of indemnity coverage. An administrative mechanism will be established to support levies on doctors to pay for the IBNR scheme and the enhanced UMP guarantee. The Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 supports the levy for the IBNR scheme on doctors in those MDOs with unfunded liabilities. The Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 allows for a levy on UMP members to cover the cost to the Commonwealth of any payment under the deed of indemnity between the Commonwealth, UMP, Australasian Medical Insurance Limited or AMIL and the provisional liquidator of UMP-AMIL. The Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002 will provide for amendments to other acts necessary as a result of the medical indemnity bills.

The government's incurred but not reported scheme will assist those MDOs which have unfunded IBNRs as at 30 June 2002 to pay those claims when they crystallise. The Commonwealth will help these MDOs to pay claims for which they had not adequately provisioned in the past. This scheme will give affected MDOs the chance of a fresh start, unencumbered by past unfunded IBNRs. The IBNR scheme consists of two parts. Firstly, the Commonwealth will provide funding for MDO IBNR liabilities that are unfunded as at 30 June 2002, with payouts beginning in early 2003. Secondly, it will recoup the cost of funding those liabilities through a levy on members of the MDOs with unfunded IBNRs. It is important to note that the members of medical defence organisations whose incurred but not reported claims are fully funded as at 30 June 2002 will not pay the levy. It is also important to noteâand I know medical practitioners in the Cowper electorate will welcome thisâthat those who belong to medical defence organisations that have fully provisioned for their IBNRs will not be subject to the levy. For those practitioners who are liable to pay the levy, it will be set as a proportion; the maximum will equal 50 per cent of the medical indemnity premium they paid in the 2000-01 financial year. This means that it will reflect the risks borne by different practitioner groupsâan approach that is strongly favoured by medical organisations.

In this package of bills the Commonwealth will also introduce a scheme, known as the High Cost Claims Scheme, to address the issue of high cost claims related to medical incidents. We are all aware of some of the recently reported landmark claims, and this scheme attempts to address the quantum of these claims. The scheme should lower premiums by reducing the potential cost of large claims to insurers. Under this scheme, the Commonwealth will meet 50 per cent of the cost of claims for payments greater than $2 million, and up to the insured amount, made by medical indemnity insurers. This scheme will apply to claims notified on or after 1 January 2003. It will not apply to claims relating to the provision of public hospital services. By meeting 50 per cent of the cost of payouts over $2 million by medical indemnity providers in relation to high cost claims, the Commonwealth is working to ensure, among other things, that adequate cover is available where incidents result in catastrophic injuries to patients. This scheme is also an effective way to address the exposure and uncertainty associated with high cost claims in medical indemnity insurance.

Premium affordability, and the consequent impacts on service provision, is a vital issue for medical practitioners, particularly in regional and rural Australia. The National Party and, indeed, the government are absolutely committed to ensure that health care providers are not restricted by prohibitive premiums in their service delivery in regional areas. If you take away the incentive to provide the care, you jeopardise the service delivery right across the nation. This particularly applies to specialists in regional areas who are facing high premiums, but who may not have the volume of clients that their metropolitan based colleagues experience. This package puts in place the foundations of the Commonwealth's subsidy scheme for doctors.

The subsidy scheme will be applied in the following ways. The subsidy will be provided to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralists who undertake Medicare billable procedures. It will be equivalent to 50 per cent of the difference between the cost of their premiums, plus the IBNR levy if applicable, and the corresponding costs for gynaecologists, general surgeons and non-procedural GPs respectively in the relevant state and territory. In light of the particularly high premium costs faced by some neurosurgeons, combined with their relatively limited scope to derive income from private practice, the subsidy rate will increase to 80 per cent on that portion of their premium, plus levy if applicable, that exceeds $50,000. Accessing the subsidy will be conditional on medical practitioners participating in quality and safety programs designed to protect patients and minimise the incidence of injuries. Approaches will be examined to minimise the need for rural doctors to be absent from their practices.

The federal coalition has shown true leadership in addressing the medical indemnity issues which have confronted doctors for the last year. We have provided a guarantee to those medical practitioners who were left exposed following the collapse of UMP-AMIL. That guarantee has now been extended to the end of 2003 to allow UMP-AMIL to make payments under cover to members and provide security during the formulation of a long-term strategy for the industry.

Today we have before us the bills which will put in place a framework which will provide security for those who provide health care right across the nation. I know my constituents of Cowper will welcome the positive outcomes which these bills will bring to our electorate. As I detailed previously, the coalition government has a proud record of addressing the challenges of providing improved health care for all Australians, particularly for those who live in rural and regional areas. When you look right across the spectrum of health care in regional areas, there are programs in place to improve the delivery of medical services: incentives for rural doctors, the education of medical staff and now, with these bills, improvements in the field of medical indemnity. All these initiatives show leadership in improving one of our key prioritiesâthe provision of better health care, particularly in regional areas.

It is therefore essential that we embrace these medical indemnity bills to make sure that insurance is affordable and that we can provide medical practitioners with the security to carry on providing first-class services to all Australians. Considerable work has been done by this government in taking the lead in tort law reform. I believe these bills, working in conjunction with tort law reform by the states, should work to substantially improve the situation in relation to medical indemnity. I must say I was pleased to hear the member for Corio offering his support for these very important bills. I commend these bills to the House.

talk.start.para: â The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, theMedical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and, last but by no means least, the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 are an interesting set of bills. This very important set of cognate bills is enough to rivet the attention of the member for Parramatta, the parliamentary secretary at the table! The member for Parramatta has seen this parliament deal with cognate bills time after time, and it has been a case of, `Well, you may as well do them as a job lot rather than take up the time of the parliament dealing with one bill after another seriatim.' Of course, these bills do share a concordance in terms of the problem that they are trying to address, but they also share a concordance in terms of what they underline as the insufficiencies (1) of the government, (2) of the medical insurance industry as a whole and (3) of insurance in Australia generally.

speech.para: These bills highlight the government's inability as a government that does not believe in being hands-onâdespite the philosophical ramifications that the member for Parramatta has attempted to introduce into the coalition: the fundamental notions of what a Liberal Party should undertake as an engaged entity, taking a Benthamite approach to trying to ensure the greatest good for the greatest number, trying to reinvigorate the party's notion of the core reality that John Stuart Mill was talking about in his great exposition On Liberty, which the member for Parramatta and others in the coalition are very au fait with. The redefinition of liberalism, which the parliamentary secretary at the table has had a great deal to do with, does not go far enough, because it cannot adequately capture the problems that there are in the market, despite the fact that the member for Parramatta is not only enamoured of the libertarian approaches taken by Bentham and Mill but also those of Adam Smith. The core and fundamental problem with Adam Smith was that his faith in the market was misplaced. Adam Smith did not understand that unregulated markets do not lead to eternal goodâyou need a sense of participatory regulation from a governmental entity to actually make the thing work competitively and to make it work properly and profitably for all involved.

Now that we have got the attention of the parliamentary secretary, despite the fact that he is actually wandering from the table to consult the Deputy Speaker, we might deal with these cognate bills and what they throw up in terms of the problems not only that society has had but also that the government has had in coming to terms with it. The medical profession in Australia is extremely important, and not only in Sydney. Bankstown airport, in my electorate, is at the geographical centre point of Sydney. The member for Parramatta understands that, because he is just outside the locus of the centre of Sydney, which is, as I said, in the electorate of Blaxland, Parramatta being proximate. The member for Lingiari, who is at the table representing the ALP, understands that medical indemnity is very important for regional Australia.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I could not hear them, but your hearing is very acute. It is another medical matter we might deal with as we deal with these bills! When we are dealing with these issues, we are dealing not only with central metropolitan concerns, such as in Sydney, which affect Blaxland and Parramatta, but with issues which affect regional Australiaâand indeed remote Australia in the case of the member for Lingiari. He is a great proponent of the need for greater resources to be centred in regional and remote Australia to deal with the particular problems that his constituents face.

speech.para: But what we face here in this cognate series of bills is a fundamental failing systemically; a fundamental failing of this government; a fundamental failing of the free market system that has so readily been apprehended and embraced by the member for Parramattaâthe good parliamentary secretary that he is, the failed interjector that he isâ
