âThe member for Parramatta understands in a primitive way that the free market economy cannot be embraced on its own. In the period of mercantilismâembracing the late 17th century to the early 18th century and into the 19th century when mercantilism merged into the great age of industrialism between 1870 and 1900âwhat was laid open and bare to the bone was that market forces on their own, untrammelled, led to great social ills. That was apparent in the United Kingdom and the United States. It was even apparent in probably the most significant, powerful and forceful of the 1870 to 1900 industrialisersâGermany, both Prussia and the associated states. They understood that there was enormous power in education, that there was enormous power in governmental activity and that there was probably more power in that than there was in what was put forward in the US and in Britain in the ideology of mercantilism transposed into the new and unfettered industrialism.

speech.para: The Germans realised fundamentally that there was a place for the government, there was a place for a bureaucratic element and there was also a place for ensuring the end results of what governments chose to do. In doing that, in arguing that there was a place in the modern era for what we understand as a public-private partnership, they were arguing that the excesses of the late 19th century in the rogue capitalism of the United States and to a lesser extent Britain showed that you cannot have an untrammelled marketâyou could, but it probably would not be successful. Certainly you should not have a supposedly free market where the operations of the free market do not really work.

In the cognate bills that we are dealing with we are faced with a very simple problem. If you simply argue that government should get out of the area and should leave it to private industry, you cannot do it in one way only. People did argue this during the Fraser periodâpeople like the current Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong. He argued it as an unsuccessful Treasurer, one who lost almost every battle he had to the quite socialist Fraserâthat is how Malcolm Fraser is regarded as being at that time, and in fact he is regarded as being increasingly socialist with the passing of the years.

If you took the point of view of the member for Bennelong from 1974 through to the crucial period 1978 to February-March 1983âa period in which he failed on point after point in trying to introduce his philosophiesâyou would see that you cannot do it one way only. You cannot give everything to the market and expect markets to work unencumbered and to work with perfection. Even the member for Parramatta would not expect that, given the fact that the member for Parramatta has thought about these things deeply, more so than many of his colleagues, I think. It is not an unreflective acceptance of either Mill, Burkeâeven as a conservativeâor any of the other people in the current pantheon that has taken so much of a hold.

There is a fundamental reality here: if you do not pay in, you do not get anything back. The government is faced with not just a market failure; the government is faced with pure greed, pure exploitation and pure selfishness on the part of those medical practitioners who thought they had a good thing going in keeping the little racket they had organised for themselvesâthe fact that they could do medical indemnity insurance on the cheap. If you are going to do medical insurance on the cheap, there are some people who are going to be worse offâour constituents. They will be the ones who will suffer in the end. The government may also have to suffer in the end because it has to grapple with the inadequacies of what has been put up.

This is a wonderful illustration of the disconjunction between ideology and ideological approaches to things and the fundamental, practical accounting and economic realities that any organisation, any institution or any association may face. It seemed a good idea at the time for the surgeons and the practitioners to put their money into the central organisation that provided most of the funds to cover medical insurance. It was reasonable; it did not overtax them. They sort of realised that it was done on the cheap but it was a good thing at the time. We found when reality came knocking at the door that the arrangements were not right; the arrangements were transparently problematic.

Constituents of the member for Parramatta, the member for Lingiari, those who have spoken before in this debateânay, even Deputy Speaker Barresi, who is in the chairâhave realised that, without adequate resources to our local hospitals, our local GPs, our local specialists and those they refer us to in life-threatening situations, our lives are held cheaply. They are held cheaply because a number of peopleâindeed, possibly the majorityâin the medical profession thought that the deal that they were offered was too hard to refuse, that it was cheap but good, and that it might last forever.

That is a natural reaction of most people. Indeed, we see it in the parliament day after day, week after week, in the person of the Treasurer: that sort of hopeful optimism that projects whatever the current circumstances are almost exponentially into the future. We have seen it in past governments as well. But if you project current circumstances indefinitely, you will be fundamentally wrong. The medical insurance companies that failed projected current circumstances well into the future. They underprojected the demands on their funds and resources. In the end they left a set of medical practitioners high and dry because they did not tell them the truth. They were not laid open, as they would lay their patients open in surgery or under the knife in the theatre, to the practical realities of the medical situation they faced. They were not laid open to the bare accounting realities of how much money they would have to front up with in insurance terms to adequately cover their insurance risk.

This has nothing to do with the twin towers and it effectively has nothing to do with the other great area of unanswered responsibility: the question of public liability Australia wide. This has to do with a closed profession with a closed mind and a closed set of insurers who would not confront reality. This government, which does not believe in public intervention, in 1996 quite openly had a paper published that was, from memory, about one inch thick. It was wonderful and shiny, with a bright yellow cover to attract the attention of the parliamentary secretary, the Deputy Speaker or anyone else in the parliament and the National Commission of Audit. The paper basically laid out that a coalition federal government would have nothing to do with direct services to any individual in Australia because it thought its whole game was to get out of public enterprise and public responsibility.

I know that deep down in his heart of hearts the member for Parramatta would knowâas the Deputy Speaker, Mr Barresi, would knowâthat you cannot run away from reality. You cannot run away from public responsibility. There was a dysfunctional fault line at the centre of this. It was that, if no-one else fronted up to the realities of the situation, in the end the Australian buck would stop at the doorstep of the Prime Minister and this parliament. That is why we are faced with the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002.

There has been a total failure not only of the market in terms of medical insurance but also of the marketeers. There has been a total failure of the insurers who had a responsibility not only to the medical practitioners who put their funds with them but also to the patients who, in the end, were reliant on them for cover for the medical practitioners' uses. People went to Bankstown Hospital, Liverpool Hospital or any of the great hospitals in Sydneyâor, indeed, to the great hospital in Alice Springs, in the case of the member for Lingiariâto have surgery for life-threatening cases. They did not want to think too much in terms of medical responsibility and medical indemnity. If they had paid their money into private insurance or had rightly been paying their tax funds into Medicare, they would expect that, if they had life-threatening conditions, their surgeons would be there to save their lives.

If there is one fundamental in the health area, it is that you can expect that our professionalsâacting professionally and supported by a medical indemnity insurance regime that cossets and protects themâare able to do their jobs to save our lives and protect the lives of our families and friends; and that they will not have to put their professional integrity on the line to ensure that they can do their jobs. This governmentâunwillingly, let it be saidâhas been forced, in this set of cognate bills, to deal with the fact that the Australian medical profession failed. They failed to pay their money up front to cover themselves. They failed to ensure that their key insurer did the job it should have been doing from day one. It should have been covering not only the medical profession's responsibilities and liabilities but also all of their patients, so that we could be assured that if we fell into difficultiesâwhether we were on the Labor side or the coalition side and whatever our views on the market and government interventionâthen the Australian medical system and Australian medical insurance would cover us. Our doctors should have been willing to pay a high enough premium to cover themselves but also a set of premiums that was reasonable.

It is not sufficient to argue that all you have to do is cover yourself in these situations. We have had a fundamental failure of the market here. We have had that failure because the market participants were given an easy ride. They did not have to pay out the proper amounts. They did not have to contribute in order to ensure their relative safety was covered through insurance. So, in the end, the buck stops with the Australian people. In the end, all of the jargon, all of the argument and all of the ideological approachesâwhether they be Mill, the more conservative Burke or the rest of the pantheon the coalition looks toâfail. Markets always fail. Markets without government intervention and government underwriting fundamentally fail. We are here picking up the pieces and putting in the dollars because of a market failure. These bills attempt to redress it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn rising to speak on the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and related bills, I have to say that I am not going to be able to call up antecedents from the 16th and 17th centuries as the previous speaker, the member for Blaxland, did. In an electorate like mine, which goes from Broken Hill to Dubbo to Parkes, you do not have that many choices about where you can go for these kinds of specialist services. The government's medical indemnity legislation packageâspecifically, the offer to extend the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd to 31 December 2003âis the safety net rural communities must have to ensure the protection of specialist services.

speech.para: There are any number of Australians who, unfortunately, have brought about the need for legislationâwhether it be in relation to public liability in general or medical indemnityâand who have expectations that can never be met. It may be that they do not know the onus of responsibility they have to themselves or that they are expecting more of any practitioner than he or she can possibly give. This government has probably done more to improve medical services in country areas in the last six years than has been done in the last 20. The amount of moneyâsome $700 millionâthat has been put into trying to retain doctors, let alone specialist doctors, in rural areas has been quite outstanding. I would like to refer to some issues raised by the member for Lilley in his address to the House. He touched on the level of bulk-billing in Australia. The member for Lilley was very fulsome in his criticism of the government, as he always is. In an article in the Australian Financial Review of 27 November, the shadow minister for health and ageing, Mr Smith, said:

quote.para: ... the additional amount picked up by Australians and their families for increases in GP copayments alone is $331 million ...'

speech.para: This requires some in-depth examination. I am grateful to the member for Boothby, who has done a great deal of research on levels of bulk-billing. He found that in 1990-91, the level of bulk-billing for vocationally registered GPs was 70.1 per cent . In September 2002, the figure was 70.4 per centâvirtually the same. The cries that the level of bulk-billing has declined are simply fatuous. The figures are the same now as they were 11 and 12 years ago. In fact, in 1984-85, the percentage of bulk-billing for total services was 43.2 per cent. I thank the member for Boothby for his excellent research in this area.

What was the response of the government of the day in 1990-91 to the low levelâ70.1 per centâof bulk-billing? The response proposed by the then minister, the Hon. Brian Howe, to these low levels of bulk-billing was to reduce the Medicare rebate. By the way, he did not see the figure of 70.1 per cent as being low; he actually saw it as very high, dangerously high. He reduced the Medicare rebate in November 1991 by $3.50 and subsequently, in November 1992, by $1.50. This was a copayment proposal which was later withdrawn. But the government of the day and the then minister for health found that the bulk-billing rate, which was the same as it is today, was too high. Isn't it amazing how the Labor Party changes their tune?

It is very interesting to look back through timeâalthough not back to the 18th century, as the member for Blaxland did. He spoke about market forces being untrammelled in regard to the situation with medical indemnity and said that you cannot give everything to the market. Looking back in time, in answer to a question from Mr Melham about decreasing the Medicare rebate, Mr Howe said:

quote.para: I am aware of reports which say that this change will discourage bulk billing and encourage doctors to lift their fees. I must stress that the government does not control or determine doctors' charges or whether they bulk bill or raise an account to the patient. These things are determined by the competitive forces or the marketplace.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: The national health strategy background paper No. 5 on the effect of co-payments on medical care clearly demonstrates that the major reason why doctors bulk bill is the competitive pressure on them to do so. Doctors who bulk bill do so now because they know it is attractive to patients and they wish to maintain a viable practice.

quote.para: ... I am confident that Medicare will continue to operate to ensure very high rates of bulkbilling.

speech.para: Mind you, he saw 70.1 per cent as being a very high rate of bulk-billing. I do wish the member for Lilley would check Labor's history; and I am grateful to the member for Boothby for supplying those figures. According to the Labor Party and the then minister for health, we now have in Australia a very high rate of bulk-billing. In fact, were Mr Howe here now, he would no doubt still be trying to reduce the Medicare rebate through a copayment. Perhaps we should take a leaf out of Mr Howe's book when he was Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services in the Labor government.

I will comment on other suggestions for dealing with the so-called low level of bulk-billingâwhich, as we are now aware, the Labor Party in 1991 saw as a very high level of bulk-billing. It is interesting to look back and see how former Minister Howe was viewed then. I refer to the valedictory that Mr Keating, the then Prime Minister, gave for Mr Howe. He said:

quote.para: ... Brian enjoyed more substantial power than probably anybody in the Left of the Labor Party, or in the Left in Australia, since the war. While we have seen other luminaries on the stage, few have been as effective.

speech.para: `Hear, hear' to that. The minister for health saw 70.1 per cent of bulk-billing as being a very high levelâin fact, this luminary of the Left saw it as being so high that he decided it was necessary to reduce the rebate. We certainly should not ignore the advice from luminaries on the Left with regard to bulk-billing and Medicare rebates.

What theories now abound to address this level of bulk-billing? The truth is that doctors will not move from the cities to rural and regionalâ

âNo other measure will encourage doctors to come and serve in rural and regional areas. We are looking at the medical indemnity insurance scheme that was announced by the government on 23 October 2002. It is certainly looking at a subsidy; it is certainly looking at providing a backup of guarantee to many doctors in the community at large and giving them assurances that they can continue to carry on their professions. But we have to do a little more than that. We have to be able to do more than just say to them, `We're going to give you that indemnity.' We are going to have to say that we are going to provide for the future without injuring patients who may be thinking in times to come of suing their doctors or suing doctors who may be incompetent. As legislators, we need to be able to provide a package that gives the community at large a level playing field where we know where we will be going in the future. Our medical profession may say that they are highly skilled, highly trained professionals and they know what they are doing. I say to them, `You are only human. You do occasionally make mistakes.' We do not always hear about them, but still they do happen.

When we are talking about packages of bills like the one before the House tonight, we have to look at the availability of provisions for organisations that are using state government funds, federal government funds and their own funds and who are at least servicing the community. They have got to have a guaranteeâI know thatâbut so has the community.

Turning to the other bills in this cognate debate, I think of things like cost recovery. Where do we go from there? What are the major problems we may have with the package? Has there been enough consultation? Is the package itself a significant step forward? Are the goals that we are trying to achieve related to what the objectives are with the medical profession at large? Have we taken on board enough community concerns? Have we been able to evaluate some of the problems that have been experienced in the past but have now come forward as major problems?

If we look at some of the claims that have been made both at the community level and at the medical professional level, we wonder whether those claims have gone far enough. Are they substantial in terms of what they are trying to achieve? When we look at the regimes that we are trying to implement as parliamentarians and legislators, have we gone far enough? Are we looking at what the minister is trying to achieve with the factors determining what we are classifying as non-participating MDOs? Do they have sufficient funds to pay their non-reported liabilities? There are many still unanswered questions.

I know we on this side of the House keep saying that we are going to agree with the bills. We will probably move a minor amendment, and in the Senate we will probably go more definitively into the bills. But we have to give a lot of consideration to where we are going in the future and to future legislation before the House.

As I said, we certainly will support the bills. But in that support of the bills we have to be sure that we are not going to have a recurrent problem in the future. As I have said, personally I do not believe that these bills have gone far enough. I know that the Commonwealth is looking at perhaps paying a percentage of doctors' claims. We are looking at a payment that could be made by the Commonwealth to the MDOs or to the insurers being determined by a multiplying factor. I would like to have more answers as to what that multiplying factor is. I know that there are a number of exceptions, and that will be made clear in the future. In my area of Western Sydney, we have some very competent doctors; we also have some doctors who are very wary. For example, some doctors are very wary of going into obstetrics. They are saying to us, `We're going to move out of that profession because we don't believe that we're going to be covered with enough insurance indemnity to avoid facing future charges.'

We as human beings have greater expectations than we had 20 or 30 years ago. In those days, when we went into hospital and put our life into the hands of a doctor, we believed that everything they were doing was right and above board. Today we seem to question a lot more of the decisions that they are making. As a profession, doctors are also concerned about that questioningâwhether their professional capabilities are being questioned by the patient. Let me say this to the medical profession: that probably is not the case; what is being considered by the patient is the right to know.

That is what I am really saying about these bills before the House. The important thing is the right to know. Are we certain of what we are doing and what we are trying to cover? Are we certain that every step that we are taking here now is going to be covered? Are we really certain that the medical profession will be happy with this? If they are not, they are going to be coming back to usâthis year, next month, next yearâand saying, `Well, it's not enough; we are still going to abandon obstetrics' or `We're not going to go into orthopaedics' or `We've decided that we're not going to operate any more.'

We do not need that. We need to have bills that will have the answers to some of the problems that the community at large has been experiencing. We need to have the bills debated before the House when we know that both sides of the House are in total agreementâwhen we feel that every `i' has been dotted and every `t' has been crossed. I am not certain that that has happened in the cognate debate that we have before the House tonight. After talking to members of the medical profession, I am also not certain whether they feel absolutely confident of what these bills will do. I know the legislative reforms are designed to ease the pressure that has been placed on the providers of medical indemnity. I say to them, `What are the pressures? Are there more ways to overcome them?'

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: Maturity Matters Conference

talk.start.para: âThe Maturity Matters conference which was held in Perth at the end of October focused on a number of issues relating to our ageing population. They included economic and social issues brought about through Australia's declining birthrate, improved health services resulting in people living longer and employment insecurity resulting in many working people being placed prematurely in the early retirement category. We are told that, on present trends, this will result in the current job scarcity transforming into an employee and skill shortage by 2020. In the meantime, Australia has the twofold problem of older workers losing their jobs and an increasing cost of providing financial support for older Australians. There is also a problem for older Australians who have provided for their retirement in the form of superannuation, because their entitlements are being affected by the drought, overseas political issues and general fluctuations of the Australian and overseas financial markets.

speech.para: The general view is that, in order to provide for an increasing ageing population, the government needs to provide for increased spending on retirement incomes or increased contributions to superannuation funds, review health services for older Australians and provide for an increased involvement of mature-age workers in the production of goods and services. To overcome these problems, a number of dangerous suggestions are being put forward. In the Sunday Telegraph last week, there is an article which states:

quote.para: The qualifying age for a pension will be raised to 70 under a Finance Department submission to reduce the financial burden of Australia's ageing population.

speech.para: Earlier in the year, Senator Coonan actually raised the possibility of doing away with the age pension altogether. These are dangerous suggestions that would certainly be opposed by the Australian Labor Party.

On the issue of recruiting older people, the New South Wales Police Force is setting an example: people older than the normal recruiting age are now being accepted into the police force. But private employers do not appear to be recognising the value of older workers, if you take the view of the Qantas chief information officer, Fiona Balfour. She is quoted in an article in the Australian on Tuesday, 12 November, where she refers to the possible lay-off of IT staff. She states:

quote.para: This is a remarkably middle-aged groupâwe are struggling to find enough space to recruit graduates, who we can recruit for tuppence.

speech.para: Further in the article, Ms Balfour refers to a suggestion that Qantas may consider outsourcing its IT work to India. She says:

quote.para: My preference is to have the work done in Australia. The whole point is, if you want support for these older systems in the future, these skills will not be available in Australia. In five to 10 years we might have to.

speech.para: That is, they might have to outsource work to India. This raises two issues that I have spoken about in the past: firstly, the need for lifelong learning for Australian workersâwhich was another major theme of the Maturity Matters conferenceâto ensure that people's skills do not become redundant; and, secondly, the need to retain our manufacturing industry so that our skill base remains in Australia. To return to our friendly Qantas executive, Ms Balfour is further quoted as saying:

quote.para: What is the average age of this groupâ

speech.para: That reminds me of a report tabled in this parliament in June 2000 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations titled Age counts. I will quote from one submission from this report. It states:

quote.para: Drake's research shows that negative attitudes about older workers was widespread. About 70 per cent of Australian firms said that they would retrench executives over 50 ahead of others because they saw them as inflexible and unwilling to change. Negative attitudes about older executives refusing to reskill, however, are not proven since `86 per cent of senior workers are more than happy to take up training opportunities when offered to them.'

speech.para: Clearly there is a need for a change of attitude by private employers relating to the employment of older workers. A positive spin on employing older workers was put to the standing committee by Professor Encel, who explained:

quote.para: ... if you train a 25-year-old in cutting edge technology, what you actually do is make him or her more mobile. So the guarantee that they will stay with the firm that trained them is very thin ...

speech.para: There is no doubt that Australians are living longer, which raises many opportunities and challenges for our policy makers. Indeed, the survival of our high standard of living will depend on us harnessing the skills and commitment of our maturing population.

talk.start.para: âIn the middle of the Nowra CBD we have a very large Telstra tower. It adjoins a public car park, through which many people travel during the day. You cannot miss it. A couple of weeks ago it was the scene of a very visible, very public act of desperation. A 19-year-old man decided that he would take his life, and he selected the tower as the stage for his final act. He hung himself in full view of the public and, by this gesture, reflected a suicide carried out by his friend 12 months earlier in the very same place. You have to ask yourself why. I do not know the background of these two young men. I had never met them and I still do not know what drove them to do this. I do know that I was shocked and uncomprehending of the act, particularly that it happened in such a public fashion.

speech.para: It was very significant to me because, that very same week, I opened the Southern Highlands Yellow Ribbon for Life program. This group, of which I am patron, was set up to provide a suicide prevention program in the Southern Highlands. It is claimed that the suicide rate for the Wingecarribee Shire is higher than the state average. In fact, Bundanoon, a small town in the shire in my electorate of Gilmore, had a spate of suicides about three years ago that spiked the average and compelled me to speak in this House on the subject. This is what the Southern Highlands News wrote at the time:

quote.para: No-one knows for sure why sleepy Bundanoon has been hit with an extraordinary wave of suicides.
The reason for one death was clear enoughâthe 77-year-old business man was in failing health.
One other victim in his 30s was soon to be retrenched, but, apparently, was optimistic about his future.

The youngest victim, 19, had a secure life and a bright future. He was nothing like the stereotyped young suicide victim. He was working with his dad in the family tree-clearing business and he was popular. He had prospects, money in the bank, and the support of his mum, dad and older sister ... but none of that was in his mind when he killed himself.
In Bundanoon there seem to be few answers.

speech.para: This episode served as a catalyst for the Yellow Ribbon for Life program in the district. The theme of the program is `It's okay to ask for help'. Any attempt at suicide is a cry for help, but there needs to be someone out there to listen. When I was sent the letter of invitation to address the group, I was reminded in the background paper that each death represents between 30 and 40 attempts at self-harm. That is 30 or 40 times that someone is calling for help. Each death means it is 30 or 40 times that no-one has listened. I acknowledge the dedication of the people in the groupâpeople like Barbara McKern, who is a practising psychologist, Robin Knowles and Lee Ryall. I would like to pay tribute to them and everyone associated with suicide prevention.

I was moved by a young survivor, Andrew Cairns, who spoke honestly and eloquently. Because he went through the experience himself and was brought back from the brink, his story was all the more compelling. As he said, he was at a low point and, through the simple act of intervention, he has moved on. Barbara says that suicide is a permanent solution to a temporary problemâhow true. If there is someone there who can reach through the darkest gloom and throw us a lifeline by giving us options, that is all we need. While I was at the opening, sitting listening and watching, I was taken by the sense of community and the spirituality that filled the room. You could hear a pin drop. Some were listening intently, as I was; some were weeping silently; and some were engrossed in their own thoughts. I had seen nothing like it, and I was moved to share this with you.

Kevin O'Neill is the temporary head of the mental health team in the district. He was instrumental in getting the program under way and is a man committed entirely to his beliefs. Kevin felt there had to be a way of telling someone that you wanted help, and a card to pass to a trusted friend is perhaps a way of doing this. In a time of need, the card, which will be distributed throughout the community, can be given to someone prepared to listen. People wearing a yellow ribbon have registered their interest in being prepared to listen. These people have been given initial training to give help in whichever way they can. The card has on it instructions for the listener. I also acknowledge the contribution of the Rotary Club of Mittagong and Bowral, which paid for the cards to be printed. The Wingecarribee Health Service is also a willing participant in this most commendable program.

Suicide is a waste, but it can be prevented. We need to be aware that each and every one of us is a tool that can help. All we need do is stop and genuinely listen. It takes only a moment to stop and listen, but it can be the difference between life and death. I commend the Yellow Ribbon campaign to the House.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to comment on a petition by over 800 residents of my own electorate and the adjacent electorate of Parramatta with regard to bulk-billing. The only apology I would make is that the petition was signed before the situation had deteriorated further. It is a constantly worsening situationâeven since those people expressed their concerns. As other speakers have indicated, we have seen a deterioration from 80.6 per cent when the Howard government was elected to a situation today where only 71 per cent of visits are bulk-billed. Admittedly, in the short term in my electorate the trend has not significantly changed, nor has it changed significantly in the adjacent Western Sydney electorates. I was at a meeting the other day when this petition was being discussed, and a person in the audience volunteered that their family doctor of 25 years in Eastwood had decided to bail out.

speech.para: In some ways, this is a repetition of a previous historical pattern. In 1975, Prime Minister Fraser indicated that he was committed to this style of system and then undermined it. In the 1980s, the current Prime Minister said he was going to take the knife to Medicare and then of course at the 1996 elections, in a clearly pragmatic tactic, decided that he had had some conversion, that Medicare was a good thing and that he was not going to undermine it. But the reality is that, through its processes, this government seeks to undermine Medicare, and the question of bulk-billing is of course central. Yesterday there was debate on the National Health Amendment (Pharmaceutical BenefitsâBudget Measures) Bill 2002, which would require higher prices for very necessary medicines. It follows a variety of measures by this government.

We all know that, in this country and internationally, there is a correlation to some degree between the socioeconomic situation of people and their health, and these issues are crucial. The reality is that people are denying themselves visits to the doctor because they cannot afford to go. We have seen the erosion of the Medicare presence within my electorate. During the period of this government, we have seen the closure of the Medicare offices in Auburn and Merrylands and the related difficulties that have arisen from those closures. An article in the Medical Journal of Australia of May 2000âwhich is still apposite todayâsays:

quote.para: With few exceptions, the evidence shows unequivocally that people of `low' SESâ

speech.para: socioeconomic statusâ

quote.para: however defined, have higher mortality rates for most major causes of death, experience more ill health (both psychological and psychosocial), and are less likely to take action to prevent disease or detect it at an asymptomatic stage.

speech.para: The article goes on to say:

quote.para: Children from low SES families are more likely to die as a result of injury ... and poisoning, and young adults ... of low SES experience higher all-cause mortality ...

speech.para: There are a lot of statistics which indicate this correlation between socioeconomic status and ill-health and mortality.

So, as this government drags on trying to undermine and defeat Medicare and trying to make sure that we do not have an adequate public health system in this country, in an electorate like mine, which is characterised by a high population of new arrivals and a very depressed economic circumstanceâeven when compared to other electorates of Western Sydneyâthis is a crucial situation. Recently we have even seen the IMF questioning the practices of this government, which have seen health spending go to nine per cent of GDP, mainly pushed by the 30 per cent rebate. The IMF, not a Marxist or Leninist organisation of note, commented that a very heavy burden on public finances was being produced by this government's policies.

The situation has not been adequately addressed by this government. The minister responsible has been silent about gap costs and silent about the drift to public hospitals as people try to find alternatives to the cost of going to local doctors. She has bemoaned the lack of GPs, ignoring the fact that her own government, when it first came to power, restricted people entering practice. I join with those 800 residents of my electorate in expressing concern about the deterioration of bulk-billing, which is just symptomatic of an overall attack by this government on public health and its total dependence on private health insuranceâwhich, quite frankly, will have a major impact in the long term in electorates such as mine in Western Sydney.

subdebateinfo.title: Grey Electorate: Rural Australians for Refugees

talk.start.para: âTonight I have an unusual thing to do, and I do it with a sense of privilege. I am presenting a statement on behalf of Dr Peter Munn, Ms Marie Kennedy and Mr Digby Wilson, who are members of Whyalla Rural Australians for Refugees. I endeavour to represent all the people in my electorate, regardless of whether or not they vote for meâand this is such a case. The statement reads as follows:

quote.para: Whyalla Rural Australians for Refugees is part of a national organization that has been formed to help other Australians view refugees and asylum seekers as human beings with their own wants and needs. Since May 2002, three Rural Australians for Refugees groups have come into existence in the Grey electorate alone, to join with over twenty-five Rural Australians for Refugees groups around Australia.

speech.para: They acknowledge and appreciate that I, am prepared to present this statement to the House on their behalf. They continue:

quote.para: Rural Australians for Refugees exists as the voice of many concerned Australian citizens who feel that their legitimate concerns are not being heard and considered by policy makers. Their concerns centre on the detention of asylum seekers who assumed, under United Nations Conventions, that Australia would treat them with dignity and humanity and assess their claims for asylum under due process.

speech.para: I intercede here to quietly remind my constituents that at least 95 per cent of these people are already in Australia and have been granted temporary protection visas. The statement continues:

quote.para: Clearly, this has not occurred with some refugees still held in detention for periods of time exceeding two years. The terrifying impact on the mental health of these people, especially children, has been well documented and has been written about even by popular and conservative magazines such as `Women's Weekly'.

speech.para: They share with all Australians a real concern for Australia's well-being, but in addition, are dismayed at the present policy concerning refugee intake and the seemingly unfeeling and bureaucratic processing of the detained applicants. They are concerned about the apparent inability of Australians who disagree with the current policies to have their views given due weight and that their expressed concerns are seen as political opposition, or worse, as disloyalty to Australia. There is a huge need to humanize the way in which these traumatized people are received into Australia, if for no other reason than that many may well become residents following processing.

I find it hard to imagine that, in peaceful Australia, these people who come to us would be more traumatised here than the alternativeâthe overseas countries they came from. But that is just my personal view.

They believe that mandatory detention is an abhorrent policy that dehumanizes people. It fails to show any respect for the worth of each person, whether an adult or child. They believe that people should only be held in detention to establish their identity and for clearance from any criminal behaviour. The model adopted in Sweden, where children are only held in detention for a maximum of six days is one that has the support of my consituents. They continue:

quote.para: Whilst children and adults are held in detention at Woomera and now at Baxter, both of which are in the Electorate of Grey, their detention should be for the shortest time possible. Further, all attempts must be made to ensure that conditions inside these centres respect the rights of the detainees to: -

speech.para: Â· appropriate health care
Â· appropriate formal education for all children under 18 years of age
Â· an appropriate place of worship
Â· free play areas for all children
Â· all families being able to gain privacy, and
Â· all detainees being able to receive visitors with a genuine concern for their welfare.

quote.para: No stone should be left unturned to ensure that the physical, mental and spiritual well being of each person is protected whilst they are placed at the detention centres.

speech.para: They believe that shaping public policy should not be based solely on the perceived dominant view of the day. History has shown that populist views can changeâas witnessed by Vietnam and the lifelong emotional scars borne by the service men and women who bravely risked their lives for us and who, upon their return to Australia were roundly denigrated.

Whyalla Rural Australians for Refugees would welcome the opportunity to have a number of refugee or asylum seeker families join their communityâto socialize with them, to share their common humanity and their different experiences and knowledge and to ensure that they minimize the emotional scars for at least a few of their traumatized brothers and sisters. It has happened in other countries in the world most successfully and it is time that Australia adopts a community re-settlement process.

Just today the minister spoke on this very issue. In summing up, I simply put the minister's positionâand mineâto my constituents: the government believes that this policy has actually saved lives by challenging the tragic trade in human beings by people smugglers.

talk.start.para: âIn the limited time available at this late hour, I want to talk about one opportunity apparently lost and my fear about the possible loss of another. I refer to the Greater Sunrise and Bayu-Undan gas projects, two resource projects in the Timor Sea which, if brought to fruition, are worth almost $10 billion between them. Both are critical to the economy of the Northern Territory and, indeed, critical to the broader Australian economy. Delivering natural gas onshore from both fields is a matter critical to the national interest, yet the Howard government sits on its hands while Rome burns.

speech.para: The venture partners in the Greater Sunrise gas project are poised to announce that they are abandoning the option of bringing gas from that field onshore for the domestic market. Meanwhile, the 31 December deadline for the Bayu-Undan project is approaching fast and, despite reports that Ministers Macfarlane and Downer have responded to Labor's call to urgently visit Dili, the ratification of the Timor Sea Treaty appears no closer. Bayu-Undan venture partner Phillips Petroleum has expressed fear that delays in the finalisation of the treaty could result in the loss of its LNG contract with its Japanese customers. Further, East Timor's Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri has accused the Howard government of putting obstacles in the way of the ratification of the treaty.

One of the great success stories to come out of the history of Australia's resources sector is the North West Shelf venture. After $13 billion of capital expenditure, it is responsible for 80,000 Australian jobs both directly and indirectly, annual export sales of $3 billionâthat is a pre China contract figureâand annual royalty payments to government of around $303 million. Of course, with the construction of a fourth train on the Burrup and the recently secured contract with China, those numbers are all set to rise. I have expressed some concern about the China contract, but there is no time to develop that argument tonight. The point I do want to make tonight is that the North West Shelf project would not have come to fruition without creative government thinking and support.

The Western Australian government lead by Charles Court guaranteed a domestic gas market. Paul Keating, as the Commonwealth Treasurer, provided special taxation arrangements to ensure the project's commercial viability. The Sunrise field is the only field in the Timor Sea with sufficient reserves to fuel the industrialisation of the Northern Territory and to provide an additional source of competitive gas to the south-east market. Of course, the Northern Territory government does not have the resources to do what Charles Court did, but it has been very active in pursuing the Domgas option at every opportunity. In fact, Chief Minister Clare Martin has personally and aggressively pursued the cause.

The Howard government stands condemned for its inaction on the Sunrise gas issue. If the government is not prepared to become sufficiently active at the eleventh hour to ensure Sunrise gas comes onshore, it should move to guarantee the retention of the resource until such time that the market for domestic gas is sufficiently large to accommodate the domestic gas option. It has that power.

The oil majors should not escape a mention. It is time we looked at market concentration in the upstream oil and gas markets to ensure that, in all cases, the national interest receives absolute priority. With respect to the Bayu-Undan field, which Phillips wants to bring onshore to an LNG plant at Wickham Point, the clock is tickingâtime is running out. The deadline for the ratification of the Timor Sea Treaty is 31 December. Legislation required to give effect to the ratification requires the support of both the House and the Senate. Yet, no such legislation has been introduced or foreshadowedâI have checked those facts with the whip tonight. There are only six sitting days to go before the summer recess and things are looking decidedly grim for the Bayu-Undan project. I call upon the government to act and to act fast. The national interest demands it.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to inform the parliament of the magnificent heart and generosity of one of the towns in my electorate of Eden-MonaroâNarooma. I am proud to say this town on the far South Coast of New South Wales has taken a leading approach to help out our drought stricken farmers, in particular, those in the Boggabri district of western New South Wales.

speech.para: In the past two weeks, the people of Narooma have donated more than $50,000 in cash, plus donations of goods, for families doing it tough this Christmas. Members of the Narooma community have worked very hard putting together hampers that were then delivered to the Boggabri district. As the Narooma News has reported, the fundraising is part of the `Adopt a town' program, which is the brainchild of local businessmen Bob Rushton and Chris Scroggy. The money will be used to provide vouchers to families in need to use at local businesses. This is a great idea because it not only puts food on the table but also helps to keep the shops in business and their staff employed. The Narooma News said:

quote.para: The hardship that the people of Boggabri have had to endure did not start with the drought but will stay with them long after the drought has broken. The floods in 2000 wiped out their lucerne crops and drought unlike flood or bushfire requires a much greater recovery time. When the lands have been burnt or flooded the recovery process can begin immediately. This is not the case when drought strikes the land. If the drought did break in the next few weeks, it would still be this time next year before any cash producing crops could be harvested and the situation is even more critical within the beef producing industry. Once the drought breaks and feed becomes readily available to livestock it is highly unlikely that breeding beef cows will produce saleable calves for the markets in less than two years. Bill Crawter, who's a councillor for Anglicare told the Narooma News, `there are people that don't have drinking water and families that are forced to live on one meal a day'.

speech.para: I also point out to the parliament that, like most of Australia, many parts of Eden-Monaro are also very dry. I have been contacted by a number of dairy farmers in the Bega Valley who can no longer afford to feed their herds. On the Monaro, many producers have been forced to sell off large numbers of cattle. In fact, I am advised that the Cooma based abattoir, Monbeef, plans to employ an extra 15 workers and start an extra shift in the near future to deal with the extra influx.

I am sure decent rain is the No. 1 item on everyone's Christmas list this year. While parts of the Monaro are part of that one per cent of New South Wales that is not drought declared, they too are drying very quickly. It is an unusual situation in that the Monaro is usually one of the first to experience dry conditions. I guess they deserve a bit of a reprieve this time after the seven years of drought they had in the mid to late nineties, which was unbelievably devastating. So, while certain parts of the Monaro have managed to come through okay, they are drying very quickly and I don't think that that good fortune will last too much longer.

In the meantime, the federal government is providing extensive practical support for farmers affected by drought. This includes exceptional circumstances support, in which the states lodge applications. Since 1997, the Commonwealth government has provided over $218 million in exceptional circumstances support for drought-affected farmers. In the current drought, the Commonwealth could pay this amount again in 2002-03 alone. There is also tax reliefâmeeting tax obligations can often be tough in such circumstances, and there are some ways to help there. At the end of last week the Prime Minister announced additional assistance measures: earlier access to farm management deposits; up to $2 million for personal counselling in 2002-03; the provision of $10 million by the Australian Government Envirofund drought funding round; $1 million in 2002-03 for the pest animal management grant program; and $1 million in 2002-03 for the Country Women's Association Emergency Aid Fund, which will also be of great assistance.

I applaud Bob Rushton, Chris Scroggy and all those who have helped them demonstrate Narooma's great generosity. Almost everybody has made some sort of contribution towards the appeal, big or small. The generosity of those in Narooma just proves the spirit Australians possess when our fellow countrymen are in need. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Ministers Department and (ii) agencies within the Ministers portfolio as at (a) 30 March 1996 and (b) 30 June 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did he receive a request from the Lithuanian Government in October 2001 asking for assistance to locate 22 alleged Lithuanian war criminals believed to be living in Australia.
(2) Did the Lithuanian authorities give any indication of the crimes the 22 suspects were alleged to have committed and did they involve the killing mainly of Jews.
(3) How many of the 22 alleged war criminals did the Australian Federal Police (AFP), at the request of his Department, find in Australia and were the Lithuanian authorities informed.
(4) What action, if any, have the AFP taken against the suspects.
(5) Have the Lithuanian authorities indicated what charges they intend to lay against the suspects and have they requested the extradition of the suspects.
(6) Will his Department take any further action against the suspects.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) On 30 September 2001, the Attorney-General's Department received a letter from the Prosecutor General's Office of the Republic of Lithuania asking for Australia's assistance in determining whether 22 named persons ever entered Australia and if so, whether they are alive or dead. If they are alive, the Lithuanian authorities asked for their current address. If they are dead the date, fact and official confirmation of death was sought.

(2) The letter from the Prosecutor General's Office of the Republic of Lithuania states that the persons on the list are suspected of genocide and war crimes against civilians, including persons of Jewish nationality during World War II. Precise details of the alleged offences were not provided.
(3) The AFP has located addresses in Australia for nine persons on the list. The Prosecutor General's Office of the Republic of Lithuania has been informed.

(4) The AFP has not taken action against any person named in the list. At the request of the Attorney-General's Department, the AFP has conducted enquiries to ascertain the whereabouts of the person on the list. Those enquiries are continuing.

(5) The Lithuanian authorities have indicated that there is insufficient evidence to lay charges against any persons on the list, but they are continuing to examine information provided to them. They have not requested the extradition of suspects.
(6) The Attorney-General's Department and the AFP will respond to any further requests that the Lithuanian authorities make.
